home.subtitle: Explore the history and philosophy of two major ideologies
home.marxContent: (1818‚Äì1883) was a German philosopher, economist, historian, sociologist, political theorist, journalist, and revolutionary socialist. He co-authored 'The Communist Manifesto' (1848) and wrote 'Das Kapital'. His ideas had a profound influence on modern knowledge, economics, and politics.
home.engelsContent: Born on November 28, 1820 in Barmen, Prussia, Engels became one of the greatest revolutionary activists. Together with Karl Marx, he co-founded Scientific Communism, leaving a lasting impact on the international workers' movement.
home.leninContent: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin was the leader of the Russian revolutionary movement. He developed Marx and Engels' theory, founded the Communist International, and led the October Revolution (1917) to establish the world's first workers' and peasants' state.
home.section1Content: Before Marx and Engels, many thinkers envisioned a just society without oppression. However, these theories lacked scientific basis and remained 'utopian'.

introduction.subtitle: 1. Two different approaches to socialism
introduction.paragraph1: Utopian socialism emerged in the early 19th century, initiated by thinkers such as Saint-Simon, Fourier, and Owen. It was based on moral ideals and aspirations for justice but lacked scientific foundation and revolutionary practice.
introduction.paragraph2: Scientific socialism, built by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in the mid-19th century, relied on scientific analysis of society and historical development laws, becoming the foundation of the modern workers' movement.
introduction.diff1: Utopian: Based on morality, compassion ‚Üí impractical.
introduction.diff2: Scientific: Based on historical materialism, analyzing social development laws ‚Üí practical and tied to reality.
introduction.roleText: Scientific socialism provides methods, theory, and revolutionary strategies for the workers' movement.
introduction.captionUtopian: Utopian Socialism ‚Äì Ideals, morality, lacking scientific foundation
introduction.captionScientific: Scientific Socialism ‚Äì Scientific foundation, linked to workers' movement

section1.title: The Communist Manifesto (1848)
section1.intro: A classic work by Marx & Engels, presenting for the first time the comprehensive system of scientific socialism, becoming the program of struggle for the international workers' movement.
mainPoints: The history of human society is the history of class struggle.
The working class is the revolutionary force to abolish capitalism.
The ultimate goal: building a communist society ‚Äì classless, without oppression or exploitation.
section1.impact: Became the program of struggle for the international workers' movement.
section1.caption: First edition of The Communist Manifesto
section1.paragraph1: The Communist Manifesto was published in 1848 in London.
section1.paragraph2: It immediately became the common program for revolutionary workers' organizations.
section1.paragraph3: Translated into many languages, it spread widely across Europe and beyond.
section1.paragraph4: Its historical value endures as a call to unity and struggle.
section1.quote: "The free development of each is the condition for the free development of all."

section2.title: The Development of Scientific Socialism by Lenin
section2.intro: Lenin developed scientific socialism to suit the new era, when capitalism entered the stage of imperialism, with wars and increasingly intense class conflicts.

highlight.title: Key points
items: Proposed the Communist Party of a new type ‚Äì the vanguard of the working class.
Affirmed that socialist revolution could break out first in some countries, not necessarily simultaneously worldwide.
Developed the theory of the socialist state and the dictatorship of the proletariat.

extra.title: Additional premises
items: Capitalism shifted to the stage of imperialism ‚Üí contradictions intensified.
The working class and revolutionary movements developed.
Context of world wars and social crises.

section2.caption: Lenin ‚Äì developer of Marxism in the new era

vietnam.title: Ho Chi Minh and Scientific Socialism in Vietnam
content: Ho Chi Minh creatively applied scientific socialism in Vietnam: the colonial revolution could succeed before the proletarian revolution in the metropole.
He led the founding of the Communist Party of Vietnam, the democratic and socialist revolutions, and the 36-year renewal process.

section3.title: Application of Scientific Socialism in Socialist Countries
section3.intro: Revolutionary movements worldwide flexibly applied scientific socialism, each in its own context, but all based on Marxism‚ÄìLeninism.
section3.caption: Scientific socialism applied in different countries

countries.ussr: The first socialist state, born from the October Revolution.
countries.china: Combined scientific socialism with rural realities.
countries.vietnam: Consistently followed the path of socialism, linked with national liberation.
countries.cuba: The socialist path in Latin America.

section3.conclusion: Although each country has different conditions, all relied on scientific socialism as the foundation for development.

section4.title: The Contemporary Significance of Scientific Socialism
section4.intro: Scientific socialism is not just a theoretical doctrine, but has become a material force and a global movement.

science.title: A scientific basis for social analysis
science.content: Provides dialectical and historical materialism, explaining the essence of human society and class contradictions.

movement.title: Guiding light for the international workers‚Äô movement
movement.content: Since the late 19th century, scientific socialism became the theoretical foundation for workers‚Äô organizations and revolutionary movements.

state.title: Formation of the socialist state system
state.content: The victory of the October Revolution in 1917 opened a new era: scientific socialism realized as a state.

values.title: Long-term, enduring values
values.content: Despite global changes, scientific socialism remains the ideological foundation for many communist and workers‚Äô parties.

section4.finalQuote: "It can be said that scientific socialism is both the torch of theory lighting the way, and the political‚Äìsocial driving force for the workers‚Äô movement and oppressed nations."

infographic.subtitle: UTOPIAN SOCIALISM & SCIENTIFIC SOCIALISM
infographic.intro: Socialism has gone through many stages of development. From the early humanitarian thinkers' ideal dreams, to the scientific theories of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, socialism gradually became a social movement with a clear theoretical basis and method of struggle.
infographic.conclusionText: Utopian socialism left behind humanistic values and ideals of justice, while scientific socialism provided the theoretical foundation, method, and strategy for the working-class movement to realize those goals. Both played important roles in the history of humankind.

socialistComparison.subtitle: 2. Comparison of Utopian Socialism and Scientific Socialism

criteria.title: Period
criteria.utopian: Early 19th century, capitalism emerging, working class not mature.
criteria.scientific: Mid 19th century (after 1848), working class formed and struggling strongly.

criteria.title: Theoretical basis
criteria.utopian: Based on moral ideals, altruism, and aspiration for fairness.
criteria.scientific: Based on historical materialism and dialectical materialism; scientifically analyzing social development laws.

criteria.title: Goal
criteria.utopian: Dream of building a fair, equal, and charitable society.
criteria.scientific: Build a communist society through class struggle and proletarian revolution.

criteria.title: Method
criteria.utopian: Proposes ideal models (communal living, fair distribution‚Ä¶), but no concrete implementation.
criteria.scientific: Linked with labor movement, political struggle, social revolution, organizing revolutionary party.

criteria.title: Representative figures
criteria.utopian: Henri de Saint-Simon, Charles Fourier, Robert Owen.

criteria.title: Advantages / Limitations
criteria.utopian:
Advantages: inspires desire for justice, highlights capitalist injustice.
Limitations: lacks scientific basis, impractical in reality.
criteria.scientific:
Advantages: scientific, practical for workers‚Äô movement, revolutionary guidance.
Limitations: needs to be supplemented and developed through historical practice.

questions.question: What does 'Utopian Socialism' emphasize?
questions.explanation: Utopian Socialism focuses on moral ideals and ideal social models, proposed by thinkers like Owen and Fourier, without a scientific basis.

questions.question: Which document marks the transition to Scientific Socialism?
questions.explanation: The Communist Manifesto by Marx and Engels in 1848 marks the shift from Utopian to Scientific Socialism.

questions.question: Who is the central subject of Scientific Socialism?
questions.explanation: The working class is considered the central force in Scientific Socialism, leading social revolution.

questions.question: What lesson did the Paris Commune (1871) provide?
questions.explanation: The Paris Commune demonstrated that workers could self-manage the state, an advanced model of Scientific Socialism.

questions.question: In Vietnam, 'socialist-oriented market economy' emphasizes:

options.text: Growth with fairness, social welfare, state role

questions.explanation: Vietnam's socialist-oriented market economy combines economic growth with social equity and state governance.

questions.question: Who laid the foundations of Utopian Socialism?
questions.explanation: Robert Owen was one of the earliest Utopian Socialists proposing ethical and cooperative ideal communities.

questions.question: What is the key difference between Scientific and Utopian Socialism?

options.text: Based on scientific and economic analysis

questions.explanation: Scientific Socialism by Marx and Engels relies on historical and economic analysis, unlike Utopian Socialism which is based on subjective ideals.

questions.question: Which work of Marx & Engels is the theoretical foundation of Scientific Socialism?
questions.explanation: The Communist Manifesto (1848) lays the foundation of Scientific Socialism with a class struggle perspective.

questions.question: When did Utopian Socialism mainly appear?
questions.explanation: Utopian Socialism flourished in the 18th century with thinkers like Rousseau, More, and social reformers.

questions.question: What is the ultimate goal of Scientific Socialism?
questions.explanation: Scientific Socialism aims for a classless society where people are liberated from economic and social oppression.
